articles.headline: Revenge in Drug War Chills Mexico
articles.snippet: Gunmen killed four relatives of a sailor who died last week in a special forces assault that killed a top drug lord.
articles.abstract: Gunmen killed four relatives of a sailor who died last week in a special forces assault that killed a top drug lord.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  It had been an elaborate farewell to one of Mexico’s fallen heroes.

articles.headline: On Web, Workshops to Create One-of-a-Kind Gifts
articles.snippet: Web sites that help people create one-of-a-kind gifts are reporting sizzling sales growth this holiday season.
articles.abstract: Web sites that help people create one-of-a-kind gifts are reporting sizzling sales growth this holiday season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Searching for meaning beyond a price tag, more holiday shoppers are giving custom-made gifts this year.

articles.headline: Latino Leaders Use Churches in Census Bid
articles.snippet: A nationwide drive urging Latinos, especially illegal immigrants, to participate in the census is focusing on evangelical churches.
articles.abstract: A nationwide drive urging Latinos, especially illegal immigrants, to participate in the census is focusing on evangelical churches.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  Fearing that millions of illegal immigrants may not be counted in the 2010 census, Latino leaders are mobilizing a nationwide drive to urge Hispanics to participate in the survey, including an intense push this week in evangelical Christian churches.

articles.headline: No Perk Too Small for Top Fliers
articles.snippet: As once-elite tiers get crowded, airlines are providing even more rarefied ones, with more perks, for the biggest spenders among their customers.
articles.abstract: As once-elite tiers get crowded, airlines are providing even more rarefied ones, with more perks, for the biggest spenders among their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: United States airlines have cut back on all but the most basic services in recent years  for most passengers.

articles.headline: Nice Home. Where’s the Rest of It?
articles.snippet: The practice of stripping and selling items from homes scheduled for foreclosure appears to be worse in boom-and-bust regions.
articles.abstract: The practice of stripping and selling items from homes scheduled for foreclosure appears to be worse in boom-and-bust regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The author of the Craigslist posting in Las Vegas made no effort to disguise his or her intentions.

articles.headline: Plan to Move Guantánamo Detainees Faces New Delay
articles.snippet: Rebuffed by lawmakers when it sought finances to buy an Illinois prison, the Obama administration is unlikely to close the Guantánamo Bay prison until 2011 at the earliest.
articles.abstract: Rebuffed by lawmakers when it sought finances to buy an Illinois prison, the Obama administration is unlikely to close the Guantánamo Bay prison until 2011 at the earliest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Rebuffed this month by skeptical lawmakers when it sought finances to buy a prison in rural Illinois, the Obama administration is struggling to come up with the money to replace the Guantánamo Bay prison.

articles.headline: Weighing Medical Costs of End-of-Life Care
articles.snippet: A medical center’s experience shows the difficulty of knowing which critically ill patients will benefit from a high-intensity approach.
articles.abstract: A medical center’s experience shows the difficulty of knowing which critically ill patients will benefit from a high-intensity approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center, one of the nation’s most highly regarded academic hospitals, has earned a reputation as a place where doctors will go to virtually any length and expense to try to save a patient’s life.

articles.headline: Last Call on Reforming Health Reform Bill
articles.snippet: House and Senate negotiations could decide how well the bill deals with rising costs and uneven quality of care.
articles.abstract: House and Senate negotiations could decide how well the bill deals with rising costs and uneven quality of care.
articles.lead_paragraph: I recently sat in on the daily meeting of a palliative care team at a hospital  doctors, nurses, a social worker, a chaplain and others, all working with seriously ill patients in extreme pain. One of the patients was a middle-aged man whose advanced cancer had destroyed a major bone in his leg. His wife had already done heroic work caring for him, and more was going to be needed in the months ahead.

articles.headline: Trial in China Signals New Limits on Dissent
articles.snippet: Liu Xiaobo, one of China’s most vocal democracy advocates, faces up to 15 years in prison on charges of “incitement to subvert state power.”
articles.abstract: Liu Xiaobo, one of China’s most vocal democracy advocates, faces up to 15 years in prison on charges of “incitement to subvert state power.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Liu Xiaobo, one of China’s most prominent advocates of democratic change, was tried Wednesday on charges of subversion, a sign that Chinese leaders are reducing their already limited tolerance for peaceful political dissent.

articles.headline: BlackBerry Breakdown Puts Users in Uproar
articles.snippet: Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, provided few details about the breakdown in service.
articles.abstract: Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, provided few details about the breakdown in service.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  Given their dependence on the device, it is no surprise that many BlackBerry owners are quick to complain when their smartphone fails to deliver on its promise of offering e-mail anywhere, at any time.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Liz Robbins
